title: Test Chrome DevTools MCP for agent browser automation
description:
Quick spike to verify Chrome DevTools MCP works for our use case.

## Install
```bash
claude mcp add chrome-devtools -- npx -y chrome-devtools-mcp@latest
```

## Test Plan

1. **Navigate** - Open a webpage (e.g., https://example.com)
2. **Click** - Click on a link/element
3. **Inspect DOM** - Use `take_snapshot` to see page structure
4. **Screenshot** - Use `take_screenshot` to capture visual state
5. **Console access** - Use `list_console_messages` to read dev console output
6. **Script execution** - Use `evaluate_script` to run `document.title` or `getComputedStyle()`

## Success Criteria
- Headed browser window opens (Jason can watch)
- All 6 capabilities work
- Console messages are accessible (key painpoint)

## Fallback
If this doesn't work well, try Playwright MCP instead.
notes:
## Test Results - ALL PASSED

| Capability | Tool | Status |
|------------|------|--------|
| Navigate | `navigate_page` | ‚úÖ |
| Click | `click` | ‚úÖ |
| DOM Snapshot | `take_snapshot` | ‚úÖ |
| Screenshot | `take_screenshot` | ‚úÖ (viewport only) |
| Console access | `list_console_messages` | ‚úÖ |
| Script execution | `evaluate_script` | ‚úÖ |
| Computed styles | `evaluate_script` + JS | ‚úÖ |

## Decision
**Chrome DevTools MCP is the winner** for agent browser automation:
- Headed mode by default (human can watch)
- Full console access (key painpoint solved)
- Script execution for computed styles
- Network/performance tools available

## Not needed for now
- Playwright MCP: fallback if chrome-devtools issues arise
- Browser MCP: less capable, no evaluate_script
- chrome-inspector-mcp: requires extension, evaluate_script suffices

## Limitations noted
- Screenshots capture page viewport only, not Chrome UI/DevTools
- See vsbeads-uak for macOS window capture research

title: Filter presets/favorites system for Issues panel
description: Currently filtering requires manually adding multiple filters (e.g., Open + In Progress + Blocked to exclude Closed). Need a better UX for common filter combinations.
design:
**Options considered:**

1. **Preset filters** - Built-in presets like "Not Closed", "Active Work"
   - Simple UX, covers common cases
   - Limited flexibility

2. **Negated filters** - Click to toggle +/- on any filter
   - Full flexibility
   - More complex UX, needs visual indicator

3. **Default filter** - Start with a filter applied (e.g., "Not Closed")
   - Good for most common use case
   - User can clear if needed

**Recommended approach:**
Combination of 1 + 3: Filter "favorites" dropdown that preconfigures filter sets.
- Start with static built-in favorites: "Not Closed", "Active" (in_progress + blocked), "All"
- Future: Allow saving custom filter sets as favorites
- Default to "Not Closed" on load

title: Fix bd sync prefix mismatch (vscode-beads- vs vscode-)
description: bd sync fails with: "prefix mismatch detected: database uses 'vscode-beads-' but found issues with prefixes: [vscode- (16 issues)]". This prevents syncing beads to git.
design:
Error suggests using --rename-on-import flag. May need to:
1. Run bd sync --rename-on-import
2. Or fix the prefix in config.yaml
3. Or re-export with correct prefix
notes:
**Root Cause:** Bug in `internal/utils/issue_id.go:ExtractIssuePrefix` - used `strings.Index` (first hyphen) instead of `strings.LastIndex` (last hyphen). For `vscode-beads-4n2`, it extracted prefix as `vscode` instead of `vscode-beads`.

**Fix:** Already in beads main (commit 6294ef0c). New bd built at `/tmp/bd-new`.

**Workaround Applied:** Renamed prefix from `vscode-beads` to `vsbeads`.

title: Build optimized agent automation for VS Code/code-server (reduce context bloat)
description:
Chrome DevTools MCP returns ~400 lines (full a11y tree) after EVERY action. This burns through context extremely fast. Need to build custom tooling.

**Problem observed:**
- `press_key` ‚Üí 401 lines returned
- `click` ‚Üí full snapshot returned  
- Simple reload workflow = ~120KB context
- Playwright MCP has same issue (also uses a11y snapshots)

**Direction:**
Build custom tooling for optimized agent-driven VS Code/code-server automation:
1. Helper extension that exposes simple commands (reload, focus panel, etc.) callable via API
2. Custom MCP that returns minimal/filtered responses instead of full tree
3. Script-based helpers agent can invoke without snapshot overhead
4. Same pattern needed for Figma later

**Current workaround:**
- Use Chrome DevTools MCP sparingly for single feature verification
- Leave window reload to human to avoid context burn
- Hybrid: agent codes, human clicks to verify

title: Research: Agent-based VS Code extension development options
description:
Research and document the best approaches for enabling agent-driven VS Code extension development.

## Areas to investigate

### VS Code in Browser
- code-server (https://github.com/coder/code-server)
- VS Code Web / vscode.dev
- Custom builds with local extension support

### Browser Automation/MCP
- Browser MCP (https://browsermcp.io/)
- Chrome DevTools MCP (https://github.com/ChromeDevTools/chrome-devtools-mcp)
- Playwright (https://playwright.dev/)
- Other automation options

### Required Capabilities
- Start/stop VS Code, reload extensions
- Take screenshots, see logs, debug inspector
- Terminal/output panel access
- Problem panel (type errors)
- Command palette execution
- Webview inspection
- Test runner integration

### Human Participation
- VNC access for headless environments
- X11 forwarding options
- Screen sharing alternatives

## Deliverable
Research document in sandbox/ with findings, trade-offs, and recommendations.
notes:
## Research Findings

### Winning Stack
```
Chrome DevTools MCP + code-server
```

### VS Code in Browser - DECIDED ‚úÖ
| Option | Verdict |
|--------|---------|
| **code-server** | ‚úÖ WINNER - native macOS, bd socket works |
| OpenVSCode Server | ‚ö†Ô∏è Docker only, socket blocked |
| vscode.dev | ‚ùå No local extension support |

### Browser Automation - DECIDED ‚úÖ
| Option | Verdict |
|--------|---------|
| **Chrome DevTools MCP** | ‚úÖ WINNER - headed, console access, evaluate_script |
| Browser MCP | ‚ùå Less capable |
| Playwright MCP | Fallback if needed |

### Capabilities Verified ‚úÖ
- Start/stop VS Code: CLI `code-server` command
- Reload extensions: DevTools "Developer: Reload Window"
- Screenshots: `take_screenshot`
- Console access: `list_console_messages`
- Command palette: `press_key` Meta+Shift+P
- Webview inspection: `take_snapshot` sees iframe content
- Extension install: `code-server --install-extension`

### Still to Verify
- Terminal/output panel access
- Problem panel (type errors via getDiagnostics?)
- Test runner integration

### Human Participation - SOLVED
Headed browser = human watches directly. No VNC/X11 needed.

title: Test: code-server vs OpenVSCode Server for local dev
description:
Compare the two VS Code in browser options for our use case.

## Test Plan

### OpenVSCode Server (Gitpod) - Test First
```bash
docker run -p 3000:3000 gitpod/openvscode-server
```
- Open in Chrome DevTools MCP
- Install vscode-beads VSIX
- Verify extension loads, webviews work
- Check console access for errors

### code-server (Coder) - Compare
```bash
brew install code-server
code-server --bind-addr localhost:8080
```
- Same tests as above
- Compare: auth, settings persistence, extension compat

## Decision Criteria
- Extension installation ease
- Webview support (critical for vscode-beads)
- Console/error visibility
- Closer to desktop VS Code behavior
notes:
## Final Verdict

**Winner: code-server** for vscode-beads development on macOS.

---

## OpenVSCode Server (Docker) - PARTIAL ‚ö†Ô∏è

### Setup
```bash
docker run -p 3000:3000 -v $(pwd):/home/workspace:cached gitpod/openvscode-server
```

### Results
- ‚úÖ Extension installs and loads
- ‚úÖ Webviews render correctly
- ‚ùå **bd daemon socket blocked** by Docker isolation
  - Error: `connect ECONNREFUSED /home/workspace/.beads/bd.sock`

### CLI Install
```bash
docker exec <container-id> /home/.openvscode-server/bin/openvscode-server \
  --install-extension /home/workspace/vscode-beads-0.1.0.vsix
```

**Verdict**: Good for UI testing only, not full extension functionality.

---

## code-server (Native) - SUCCESS ‚úÖ

### Setup
```bash
brew install code-server
code-server --bind-addr localhost:8080 --auth none /path/to/project
```

### Results
- ‚úÖ Extension installs via CLI
- ‚úÖ Webviews render correctly
- ‚úÖ **bd daemon socket works** (native macOS access)
- ‚úÖ Full functionality - issues list, filters, everything

### CLI Install
```bash
code-server --install-extension /path/to/extension.vsix
```

**Verdict**: Full functionality, recommended for vscode-beads development.

---

## Comparison Table

| Feature | code-server | OpenVSCode Server |
|---------|-------------|-------------------|
| Install | `brew install` | Docker only (macOS) |
| bd socket | ‚úÖ Works | ‚ùå Blocked |
| CLI install | ‚úÖ | ‚úÖ |
| Webviews | ‚úÖ | ‚úÖ |
| Dev workflow | Full | UI testing only |

title: viewContainer/title buttons not showing in BEADS header
description: Configured beads.switchProject and beads.refresh commands in viewContainer/title menu with `when: viewContainer == beads`, but no buttons appear in the BEADS header. Only the [...] overflow menu shows.
design:
VS Code does not support extension-contributed inline buttons in viewContainer title bars. The `viewContainer/title` menu contribution point only adds items to the overflow/context menu.

This is confirmed by microsoft/vscode#74221 which was closed as out-of-scope.
notes:
**Finding:** This is a VS Code platform limitation, not a bug in our extension.

Per [microsoft/vscode#74221](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/74221):
- Built-in view containers (Run and Debug, Search) can have title bar buttons
- Extension view containers can ONLY add to overflow menu (...)
- Feature request was rejected as "out-of-scope"

**Current workaround:** Use `view/title` to add buttons to individual view headers (e.g., Issues panel title bar) instead of the container title bar.

**Status:** Won't fix - VS Code limitation

```bash
code-server --bind-addr localhost:8080 --auth none /path/to/project
```

### CLI Extension Management
```bash
code-server --install-extension /path/to/extension.vsix
code-server --list-extensions
```

### Why It Works
code-server runs natively on macOS, so it has direct access to the Unix socket at `.beads/bd.sock`. No Docker isolation.

### Dev Workflow
1. `bun run watch` (local rebuild)
2. `bun run package` (create VSIX)
3. `code-server --install-extension vscode-beads-*.vsix`
4. DevTools MCP: "Developer: Reload Window"
5. Test extension in browser
